title.narrative: Integrated emergency response to children, women and to vulnerable people - Internally Displaced People (IDPs), returnees, host communities affected by armed conflicts and infectious disease outbreaks in the DRC

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life- assistance across multiple sectors – including shelter and essential household items, water, sanitation and hygiene, education, nutrition, child protection – to internally displaced persons, returnees and host community members in Ituri, North Kivu and South Kivu. This UNICEF project provides a multi-sectoral package comprising vaccinations, providing protection support to children, providing essential household item support, supporting survivors of gender-based violence, rehabilitating classrooms and procuring educational materials, screening for acute malnutrition, admitting severely acutely malnourished people admitted to therapeutic feeding programmes, The shelter and essential household item component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 156,000 people; the nutrition component 71,000 people; the water, sanitation and hygiene component to 7,500 people; the education component to 4,500 people; and the child protection component to 9,500 people.

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

humanitarian-scope.narrative: CONGO, DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE VIOLENCE/CLASHES 2021

title.narrative: RESIDENT / HUMANITARIAN COORDINATOR REPORT ON THE USE OF CERF FUNDS CONGO, DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE UNDERFUNDED EMERGENCIES VIOLENCE/CLASHES 2021

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: 550 Children separated from armed groups, children separated from their families due to conflicts and other humanitarian crises and children and women survivors of violence, including GBV, are provided with appropriate, safe and quality care and protection.
# Safe, accessible, and child-friendly community mechanisms for the prevention and protection of children against sexual exploitation and abuse (PSEA) established and functional
CP.1 Number of unaccompanied or separated children identified and assisted, including family tracing and reunification
CP.2 Number of children who have exited an armed force or group and who have been provided with protection or reintegration support
H.9 Number of people provided with mental health and pyscho-social support services (women and children)
Number Mobile and fix Child Friendly Spaces functional
Number of UASC and CAAFG (girls and boys) reunified with their families and communities
Number of UASC, CAAFG and other vulnerable children (girls and boys) reintegrated in vocational training /socioeconomic reintegration
Number of people sensitized on the risks of family separation, how to mitigate the risks of and prevent GBV

PS.2 Number of people benefitting from core GBV services (e.g. case management, psycho-social support, clinical management of rape, PEP, etc.) (survivors of GBV with access to a comprehensive and holistic package of services and mitigate the risks of and prevent GBV)

7 583 children under five years old benefit from SAM services, contributing to the reduction of morbidity and mortality associated to SAM in Ituri province, Djugu territory (Mongwalu health zone) and Irumu territory (Bunia and Gety health zones), Mambasa territory (Mandima health zone), North Kivu province, Beni territory (Beni, Mutwanga, Oicha health zones), South Kivu province, Fizi territory (Fizi health zone)
N.3a Number of severely acutely malnourished people admitted to therapeutic feeding programme
N.3b Percentage of people who were admitted for SAM treatment who recovered >75%
N.4 Number of people screened for acute malnutrition
N.6 Number of people benefitting training and/or community awareness sessions on infant and young child feeding in emergencies (pregnant and breastfeeding women or other caregivers)

71,379 people affected by population movements have access to a WASH package in the territory of Djugu (Fataki and Mongwalu health zones) and the territory of Irumu (Gety health zone), Ituri province, in the Beni territory (Beni and Mutwanga health zones), North Kivu province, and in Fizi territory (Fizi health zone), South Kivu province, as well as a rapid response to cholera WASH in the South and North Kivu.
% of suspected cholera cases are responded within 48 hours after a case is notified
Number of emergency latrines built or rehabilitated in spontaneous sites or in host families or returnee families
Number of people who benefited from hygiene promotion sessions
Number of primary schools having benefited from an emergency WASH in School package
Number of rehabilitated / refurbished water points with 0 coliforms
Number of structures having benefited from a WASH in Health or Emergency Nutrition package
People living with disabilities who have benefited from actions adapted to their specific needs
WS.6 Number of people accessing a sufficient quantity of safe water as per agreed sector/cluster coordination standards and norms

90,405 people have access to measles vaccines in the provinces of North Kivu, Ituri, South Kivu, Maniema, and Tanganyika and 173 400 vulnerable people have access to NFIs in the territories of North Kivu, South Kivu and Ituri.
% of confirmed alerts are followed by rapid needs assessment
% of rapid needs assessment confirming humanitarian needs are followed by rapid response interventions
% of rapid response interventions are initiated after 7 days of rapid needs assessment (excluding transport time)
CC.1 Number of frontline aid workers (e.g. partner personnel) who received short refresher training to support programme implementation (health workers briefed correctly on measles case management)
Percentage of children aged 6-59 months diagnosed as eligible for treatment who were taken in charge of measles
Percentage of children aged 6-59 months immunize against measles in target areas
SN.2a Number of people benefitting from in-kind NFI assistance
SN.2b Number of in-kind NFI kits distributed

By the end of 2022, 4,669 children and adolescents, girls and boys located in targeted areas affected by emergencies, in particular crises, have access to and are retained in schools and learning centres in the province of North Kivu (Beni health zone) and in South Kivu (Fizi health zone)

CC.1 Number of frontline aid workers (e.g. partner personnel) who received short refresher training to support programme implementation (teachers trained at least one of the topics concerning psychosocial support for children in class, peace education and learner-centred pedagogy)

Ed.1 Number of children accessing formal or non-formal (education aged 6-17 from displaced populations, returnees and host households for 7 to 12 months with access to an inclusive, safe and protective school environment in the target health zones)
